questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of recurrent seizures. He is at the 5th percentile for height and 10th percentile for weight. Examination shows coarse pale hair, inelastic hypopigmented skin, and generalized hypotonia. Laboratory studies show low serum ceruloplasmin levels. Decreased activity of which of the following enzymes is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phenylalanine hydroxylase activity is reduced in phenylketonuria. This condition most often causes pale hair, seizures, failure to thrive, hypotonia, and skin hypopigmentation. However, this patient lacks the characteristic “musty” odor that is typical for phenylketonuria. Also, coarse hair and low ceruloplasmin would not be expected. In many countries, PKU would have been detected at birth by the newborn screening test.

B) INCORRECT:

Prolyl hydroxylase activity is diminished in vitamin C deficiency (scurvy), which can present with coarse “corkscrew”-like hair. However, other features characteristic of scurvy, such as easy bruising, poor wound healing, swollen or bleeding gums, and recurrent infections, are not reported in this patient. Also, hypopigmentation, seizures, and low ceruloplasmin would not be expected with scurvy.

C) CORRECT:

Lysyl oxidase uses copper as a cofactor in the cross-linking of tropocollagen. Reduced activity of lysyl oxidase results in the characteristic coarse, brittle, “kinky” hair and inelastic skin seen in Menkes disease. This condition is due to an X-linked recessive mutation in the ATP7A gene, which codes for a protein involved in copper absorption and transport. Because this mutation impairs intestinal absorption of copper, total body copper is low. The result is decreased ceruloplasmin levels and reduced activity of lysyl oxidase.

Tyrosinase is also a copper-dependent enzyme and its activity is compromised in Menkes disease. This is the underlying cause of the characteristic hypopigmented hair and skin.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocerebrosidase activity is compromised in Gaucher disease, which can present with failure to thrive, hypotonia, and seizures. However, other key features of this disease such as hepatosplenomegaly, recurrent infections, and bone pain (due to osteoporosis and/or bone infarcts) are absent in this patient. Also, hypopigmentation and low ceruloplasmin levels would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Homogentisate oxidase activity is decreased in patients with alkaptonuria. This condition presents with bluish-black discoloration of connective tissue (e.g., sclera, tendons, or ear cartilage) and arthralgia during adulthood. Children with alkaptonuria can present with black discoloration of urine following prolonged exposure to air but are otherwise asymptomatic. Hypopigmentation, coarse hair, failure to thrive, hypotonia, seizures, and low ceruloplasmin would not be expected with alkaptonuria.
questions.hint: Seizures, hypotonia, failure to thrive, coarse hair, inelastic depigmented skin, and low ceruloplasmin are suggestive of Menkes disease.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-week history of abdominal distention and yellowing of the skin. He also has a 2-year history of progressively worsening breathlessness and cough. Three days after admission, he suddenly develops peritonitis and sepsis. Despite appropriate care, he dies. At autopsy, histopathological examination of liver and lung tissue shows periodic acid-Schiff-positive (PAS-positive) globules within periportal hepatocytes. Further analysis shows low levels of a protein that is responsible for the recoil of the lungs during expiration. Which of the following processes most likely contributes to the elastic properties of this protein?

choices.text: Arrangement in a triple helical structure

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Elastin is a stretchy protein that is abundant in skin, lungs, certain ligaments, vocal cords, and large (elastic) arteries. The elastic recoil of elastin is predominantly due to extracellular crosslinking of tropoelastin molecules. The crosslinks are formed by transglutaminase, which forms glutamyl-lysine bonds, and by lysyl oxidase, which catalyzes the oxidative deamination of nonhydroxylated lysine residues to form polylysine crosslinks. These crosslinks in elastin undergo nonenzymatic conversion to desmosine. The enzyme lysine oxidase is also responsible for crosslinking of tropocollagen molecules, but the crosslinks of collagen are formed from hydroxylated lysine residues.

Conditions associated with defects in elastin formation include Menkes disease, Marfan syndrome, and Williams syndrome.
Image Description:

Relaxed and stretched conformations of an elastin molecule

B) INCORRECT:

Hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues occurs during collagen synthesis. Elastin, on the other hand, is rich in nonhydroxylated proline and lysine residues.

C) INCORRECT:

Collagen has a triple helical structure. Elastin, on the other hand, does not have a triple helical structure. It is formed by amorphous aggregates of tropoelastin molecules that are enclosed within a sheath of fibrillin.

D) INCORRECT:

Formation of disulfide bridges occurs during collagen synthesis. Elastin, on the other hand, does not have disulfide bridges.

E) INCORRECT:

N-glycosylation is involved in the formation of the fibrillin sheath, which in turn forms a scaffold for tropoelastin assembly and contributes to the elastic recoil of elastin. However, N-glycosylation occurs on amino acids with nitrogen atoms in the side chain (e.g., asparagine, arginine); it does not occur on serine, which has a hydroxyl group on the side chain and, therefore, instead undergoes O-glycosylation. O-glycosylation does not play a role in the synthesis or the elastic recoil of elastin. However, O-glycosylation of hydroxylysine residues is an important step in procollagen synthesis.
questions.hint: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD), which can result in early-onset emphysema and liver cirrhosis, is characterized by the presence of PAS-positive globules on liver biopsy. AAT normally hydrolyzes neutrophilic elastase in the lung. In the case of AATD, elastase activity in the lung is increased, and, consequently, the levels of elastin are decreased.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive shortness of breath and difficulty swallowing. She can no longer take long walks with her dog because she gets out of breath easily. She has also had fatigue, muscle aches, and joint pain for 6 months. She says that her fingers recently started to become pale and numb in cold water, and warm and red on reheating. She does not smoke cigarettes and drinks one glass of wine weekly. Her pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention. There is swelling and tenderness of the metacarpophalangeal joints in both hands. Cardiac examination shows accentuation and splitting of S2. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.8 g/dL


Leukocyte count
4700/mm3



Platelet count
142,000/mm3



C-reactive protein
2.2 mg/L (N = 0.08–3.1)


Serum



Creatine kinase
66 U/L


Rheumatoid factor
positive


Antinuclear antibodies
positive


Anti-U1 RNP antibodies
positive


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) may manifest with findings that largely overlap with this patient's presentation (nonspecific features of autoimmune CTDs such as arthralgia, myalgia, pulmonary hypertension, and positive ANAs). Furthermore, the characteristic malar rash is not required for diagnosis. However, anti-dsDNA antibodies are typically associated with SLE, whereas anti-U1 RNP antibodies indicate a different CTD.

B) INCORRECT:

Sjogren syndrome may manifest with dysphagia (typically due to sicca syndrome) and nonspecific features of autoimmune CTDs such as positive rheumatoid factor. However, pulmonary involvement is uncommon in Sjogren syndrome. In addition, anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB antibodies are associated with Sjogren syndrome, whereas anti-U1 RNP antibodies indicate a different CTD.

C) INCORRECT:

Polymyositis may manifest with nonspecific features of autoimmune CTDs such as myalgia and positive ANAs. However, laboratory studies in patients with polymyositis typically show elevated creatine kinase (CK), whereas this patient's CK is within the reference range. Finally, anti-Jo-1 antibodies are associated with polymyositis, whereas anti-U1 RNP antibodies indicate a different CTD.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) may manifest with dysphagia and nonspecific features of autoimmune CTDs such as arthralgia, positive rheumatoid factor, pulmonary hypertension, and Raynaud phenomenon. However, in addition to dactylitis, features of sclerodactyly (atrophic and necrotic spots) would be expected on physical examination. In addition, anti-Scl-70 antibodies are typically associated with SSc, whereas anti-U1 RNP antibodies indicate a different CTD.

E) CORRECT:

A positive test for anti-U1 RNP antibodies (a type of ANA) is highly sensitive and specific for mixed connective tissue disorder (MCTD). Other autoantibodies, such as rheumatoid factor, may also be positive (see “Overview of ANAs” table). MCTD is characterized by concurrent features of at least two autoimmune connective tissue diseases, such as systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, or idiopathic inflammatory myopathies. Features of MCTD develop over months to years and include puffy fingers, synovitis, myositis, and Raynaud syndrome. This condition is diagnosed in patients with clinical features of MCTD and a positive anti-U1 RNP antibody test. Pulmonary hypertension and interstitial lung disease are the main causes of mortality in patients with MCTD.

F) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA), especially early-stage RA, may manifest with findings that greatly overlap with this patient's presentation (arthritis of the metacarpophalangeal joints, nonspecific features of autoimmune CTDs such as myalgia and positive rheumatoid factor). However, laboratory studies in patients with RA typically show an elevated C-reactive protein (CRP), whereas this patient's CRP is within the reference range. Moreover, anticitrullinated peptide antibodies are typically associated with RA, whereas anti-U1 RNP antibodies indicate a different CTD.
questions.hint: This patient presents with nonspecific features of an autoimmune connective tissue disease (CTD), including fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia, Raynaud syndrome, anemia, and positive antinuclear antibodies (ANAs), in addition to signs of pulmonary involvement, which has led to pulmonary hypertension (e.g., dyspnea, jugular venous distention, accentuated, split S2). However, the patient's antibody test is pathognomonic for a specific CTD.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the ED after twisting her left ankle while descending stairs. She reports mild pain and no other injuries. Her medical history scoliosis diagnosed in early adolescence (shown in photograph), which has been stable for 5 years, a retinal detachment 2 years ago, and hypermobility. Cardiac auscultation reveals a soft early diastolic murmur at the left sternal border. Ankle radiograph shows no fracture. Which of the following serious complications is this patient most at risk for?

choices.text: Progressive restrictive lung disease from severe thoracic scoliosis
Ascending aortic aneurysm with risk of dissection
Mitral valve stenosis with left atrial enlargement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Severe scoliosis can cause restrictive ventilatory impairment and reduced exercise tolerance, but this complication develops gradually and the patient's scoliosis is stable. Her body shape, hypermobility, previous retinal detachment, and scoliosis suggest an underlying condition that puts her at elevated risk of other complications.

B) INCORRECT:

Uterine rupture occurs in vascular Ehlers–Danlos syndrome (type IV), a distinct connective tissue disorder caused by type III collagen deficiency. In Marfan syndrome, which this patient has multiple features of, pregnancy-related mortality is due to aortic root dilation and dissection, not uterine rupture.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's body shape, past history of scoliosis and retinal detachment, and cardiac findings suggest Marfan syndrome. Pulmonary hypertension is seen in disorders such as systemic sclerosis or lupus, not Marfan syndrome. The most common pulmonary complication in Marfan is spontaneous pneumothorax from apical blebs, not vascular remodeling.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient’s marfanoid habitus, skeletal deformities, and history of retinal detachment are characteristic of Marfan syndrome. The early diastolic murmur indicates aortic root dilation, a hallmark cardiovascular manifestation of the disorder. Progressive dilation predisposes to aortic aneurysm, aortic regurgitation, and acute dissection; the principal causes of morbidity and premature death in affected patients. In the ED, recognition of these features should prompt referral to cardiology and medical genetics for diagnostic confirmation, echocardiographic assessment of the aortic root, and strict blood pressure control with beta-blockade to reduce aortic wall stress.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse may occur in Marfan syndrome, which this patient has multiple features of, but mitral valve stenosis is not typical.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of progressive dyspnea and fatigue. She reports recent bilateral wrist pain and numbness. Physical examination shows distended neck veins, bibasilar crackles, bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, and macroglossia. Echocardiogram shows increased wall thickness with normal ejection fraction and no hypoechoic collection around the heart. ECG shows low voltage in limb leads. Urinalysis shows proteinuria. Which of the following conditions most likely explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While systemic lupus erythematosus can cause multisystem disease, including cardiac and renal involvement, the combination of bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, macroglossia, low-voltage ECG despite wall thickening (voltage-mass mismatch), and proteinuria is not characteristic of lupus.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's constellation of findings represents the classic presentation of systemic amyloidosis: bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, macroglossia, heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, low-voltage ECG despite increased wall thickness (voltage-mass mismatch), and proteinuria. Amyloidosis is a systemic connective tissue disease caused by abnormal protein deposition and can affect multiple organs simultaneously.

C) INCORRECT:

While rheumatoid arthritis can cause carpal tunnel syndrome and is a systemic inflammatory condition, it does not typically manifest with macroglossia, voltage-mass mismatch on ECG and echocardiogram, or the pattern of cardiac and renal involvement seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic sclerosis can cause multisystem involvement, including cardiac and renal disease, but findings of bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, macroglossia, and voltage-mass mismatch are characteristic of a different condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Severe hypothyroidism can cause carpal tunnel syndrome, macroglossia, and heart failure, and it can cause low-voltage ECG if a myxedematous pericardial effusion is present. This patient's echocardiogram shows increased wall thickness without evidence of pericardial effusion, and the combination of low-voltage ECG with increased wall thickness (voltage-mass mismatch) suggests infiltrative disease rather than the electrical dampening effect of pericardial fluid.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of easy bruising. He has met all developmental milestones. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows velvety, fragile skin that can be stretched further than normal and multiple ecchymoses. Joint range of motion is increased. A defect in which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

α-Collagen triple helix formation is disrupted in patients with osteogenesis imperfecta. Though this condition can manifest with easy bruising, skin hyperelasticity, and joint hypermobility, most patients also have a history of numerous fractures with minimal trauma. Other common manifestations include blue sclerae, hearing loss, and dental abnormalities.

B) INCORRECT:

α1-Antitrypsin production by the liver is reduced in patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency. In severe cases, this condition can manifest with early liver dysfunction (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis) and panacinar emphysema. This condition does not cause easy bruising, skin hyperelasticity, and joint hypermobility.

C) INCORRECT:

Fibrillin-1 glycoprotein production is disrupted in patients with Marfan syndrome, which can also cause skin hyperelasticity and joint hypermobility. However, this patient lacks other characteristic manifestations of Marfan syndrome, including tall and slender stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, pectus excavatum, and lens dislocation. Moreover, Marfan syndrome does not cause easy bruising.

D) INCORRECT:

Proline and lysine hydroxylation is impaired in patients with scurvy because vitamin C is a necessary cofactor in this process. Though this condition can manifest with easy bruising, patients also typically have signs and symptoms of malnutrition such as poor wound healing and an impaired immune response. This condition does not cause skin hyperelasticity or joint hypermobility.

E) CORRECT:

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome has several subtypes, all of which share the underlying mechanism of defective collagen synthesis and/or processing. In patients with impaired lysine-hydroxylysine cross-linking of tropocollagen (e.g., due to enzyme deficiencies), stable collagen fibrils cannot be formed, leading to the characteristic presentation seen in this patient. Defects in type III collagen and type V collagen can also cause this condition.

Problems with collagen cross-linking are also seen in Menkes disease due to decreased activity of lysyl oxidase.
Image Description:

Collagen biosynthesis starts with the translation (1) at the rough ER, during which the polypeptide chain of the collagens is modified (Hydroxylation, 2). For attaching the OH groups, vitamin C is necessary as a cofactor for lysyl hydroxylase and prolyl hydroxylase. Next, by attaching sugar molecules, hydroxylysine residues are glycosylated (3). Three procollagen chains form a triple helix (4). These very large molecules are enclosed in vesicles, transported to the cell membrane via the Golgi apparatus and secreted via exocytosis in the extracellular space (5). At this stage, the collagen triple helix is further processed: The propeptides at the end of the collagen propeptide chains are split off (6). Next, the formed tropocollagens are cross-linked to fibrils (fibrillogenesis, 7). In the extracellular space, several of these fibrils form collagen fibers (8).

Various conditions are the result of defective collagen synthesis. Examples can be found in the overlay.
questions.hint: This boy has findings consistent with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which typically manifests with easy bruising, skin hyperelasticity, and joint hypermobility.
